text: So whatever you learn in programming I think most of you start with a Hello World application So this is the thing that we usually start with with logging This is how we start This is how our logging application starts So I have a question to you Who of you have seen logs looking like that even in Yeah so have you seen these like passwords in logs right All these fancy things Yeah so I think that doesn't really get us far is it So I think we're going to have to think about telemetry in a different way and this is what Robert and I will be talking about today My name is Dan If you're from Edinburgh you might know me from drumming at weird places and parks But yeah so I do like drumming but this is not what I'm talking about today You might know me from you know this is my GitHub handle and also this is my personal website I'm a principal observability architect at New Relic I have been working in platforms for almost 15 years from for example CERN in or recently Skyscanner I'm part of the Open Telemetry Governance Committee and also maintainer of the End User Special Interest Group And I've got a book that is called Practical Open Telemetry It's about two open telemetry years old which is about like 20 years in human years And that's all about me I'm Robert Pajonc I'm not from here I'm from Krakow But who knows this place from where is this photo Yeah Yeah so I highly recommend going there So far the best place in Edinburgh in my So my handle on GitHub is Palaret I'm contributing a lot in open source mostly in open telemetry so you can find me creating pull request issues basically I work in Splunk Splunk which is a Cisco company right now similar to Isovalent is paying me for doing open source So I'm mainly a Open Telemetry Go maintainer but also a specification sponsor And I'm basically contributing to logs in open telemetry for more than two years or about two years but I was doing logging for much longer than that Disclaimer I'm not an English speaker so if you have problems understanding me it simply means that I have no idea what I'm talking about I have a question to you Dan does it mean that I just need more pillars than logs right Yeah so I think the concept of yeah there's more logs and more pillars than logs right But the concept of pillars is a bit outdated I think you know pillars as you know different isolated signals that we send to maybe one or many observability backends You might send your metrics somewhere and your logs somewhere else They create silos So if you think about telemetry and pillars it creates silos Silos between signals so like you know you don't know what's happening in metrics It's correlated to your logs It's correlated to your traces Like you know you don't have the evidence to do that So you end up basically having to manually correlate things put things in a dashboard somewhere and then sort of like see if they align And they also create silos between services You're probably deploying a complex distributed system service mesh and like you know sometimes we forget that there is an upstream and there is a downstream We just go like hey you know my service is working Everything's fine But what if you want to correlate containers or container throttling or CPU throttling and Kubernetes containers to the experience that your end users are getting like to your core work vitals You're going to need more context of that With no shared context you're missing data there right You're just basically guiding yourself by intuition rather than So it's all about context and it's all about correlation The word context is thrown around a lot in you know Gen AI these days but it's really all about context The context that you can give your observability platform to give you insights on top of that data So if you start from for example that user that's having a poor experience those core work vitals that are produced from browsers and now with OpenTelemetry we can propagate trace context all the way down from the browser to backend services What you see here is the representation of a distributed trace Thanks to Whitney I already covered before what a trace is You know each one of these is a span It goes through multiple services Each one of these colors for example here will represent a different service right But then you've got like metrics now that are correlated to the same thing In OpenTelemetry there is a concept called exemplars which give you examples of traces that were going through the system when a particular data point was recorded So if you have a team that is being alerted for a backend regression let's say on the duration or the HTTP server duration is going up now you can start to correlate that to traces that were going through that system when that increased duration was happening And we've also got semantic conventions that allows us to correlate telemetry from multiple pillars as part of the same source So it's all coming together representing the same entity right And soon we will have continuous profiling correlated to these traces as well So if you're seeing that something is happening in a trace you can sort of like double click and then go down into the call stack of that particular replica as it was recorded in a  So traces metrics we don't need logs anymore do we Robert Yeah I think that's why you were talking about context correlation and trace correlation about three minutes five minutes I think I can just add it to the logs right It will be cool Why do we need anything more So why would you just add this trace context to logs It's everything that we need So in OpenTelemetry the logs data model so this is just a memory representation It doesn't have to be JSON just a disclaimer because sometimes people ask me The telemetry is not just that It's just a text message a white line in standard output or whatever It basically is a timestamp but no there are two timestamps One is when suffix happened and second when was it recorded Then we have this trace context which Dan was talking about We have also severity and two types of severity because sometimes log records are coming from different libraries so if a textual representation for a logging library and also a number you know threshold level severity so we can filter out logs easily Also we have a Body can be for example a log message And we have additional logging fields and metadata We have also the information about instrumentation scope Instrumentation scope in OpenTelemetry can be your logger name It can be also a name of your component in your application And also in OpenTelemetry you have resource Your resource is the information about your software that you have deployed So the name of your service is working on staging the version So in OpenTelemetry logs it's just not a text with a timestamp It's a structured log so it is about structured logging And what is more interesting the data the attributes and the log message body the log record body sorry it's a complex type So we call it any value And it can be one of primitive of It can be a string number double floating number precision It can be an array of any value And it is a heterogeneous array meaning the first element can be an integer The second can be a The third can be an It can be a map from a string to any value So it gives you the opportunity to create to represent any object So you can basically for instance add as an attribute your whole payload that you're sending via an HTTP request if you want It can be a binary ledged object something which isn't supported by JSON for And it can be also an empty value because who loves nil and nulls in programming languages right Yeah so here's just an example Right now everyone is doing AI So we have an example how an attribute could look for attributes for prompts for observability for AI still I love logs Can I use logs then everywhere Do you think it will be a good decision I don't think it's about using logs or using spans or using metrics It's about using all of them I think each of them has a purpose So if we are starting with metrics I say metrics Everyone is familiar with They are a stable signal What we mean by stable signal is that it doesn't matter if your application is receiving 1 million or 1 000 requests per second You will generate metrics at a relatively stable amount of telemetry volume right So you generate them at frequent intervals So that makes the metrics and the aggregation of You have different statistical aggregations that you can create from these measurements That makes them great for alerting because they're It makes them great for long term trend analysis But they're not that good for debugging for basically understanding what goes on inside a system right But that lower volume can make them more reliable So if you're providing an SLA if you've got an observability platform and you want to provide maybe different levels of reliability for different types of data metrics is probably one where you can provide a higher SLA because you can retry metric export for longer Or you can use like pull based and then the definition of metrics becomes more or the actual resulting data may be more reliable right The important thing with metrics is to keep the cardinality low Otherwise the aggregation that we're talking about it starts to be useless As in like you know if you generate one data point per request then that doesn't really make any sense in terms of aggregation right But we can correlate them with semantic conversions and with exemplars to traces Now traces do have that high granularity that context The trace is actually the backbone of correlation for modern telemetry data So they allow you to basically debug your workloads work on optimization short term trend analysis And then you can also generate metrics from spans as well right But that high volume does mean that it's a bit more expensive to queue more expensive to retry But the good news is that with tracing and with context we can do better sampling more ways of like you know there's head sampling tail sampling There's a long like I would be here for another 20 minutes if I were to explain that So I'm not going to explain that but there are better ways of making sure that we store the information that is useful to us and discard the And for it as well we've got Logs they still have their uses right I have logs Logs We have background you know anything that is not perhaps in the context of a trace like background tasks startup shutdown We've got applications and libraries that are using login already And that you don't need to start to you know or you might not be able to move to span data or to trace data But you can inject that context into the logs and then correlate them And as well very important anything related to that requires a discrete event to be published like you know like a client site browser mobile infrastructure events JNI as Robert was just mentioning and soon profiles I think I just keep saying like soon profiles But it is coming So you will be able to correlate that as well So let's go through an example And I understand that basically this is Kubernetes community days and I'm going to be talking about Java which is my language of choice Probably not the one of many in this room But anyway so we'll go through an example of what it is to use all these three signals together What you've got here is a quick like you know Java script We're just going to run it and generate some data right The first thing we do is we get a tracer a meter and a logger that will allow us to create these instruments and this data that we'll be recording This is part of the OpenTelemetry API right We create a standard like you know list of attributes In this case we just have one single attribute in that list And we're going to use that attribute across these three things logs metrics and traces We'll register a counter metric instrument So an instrument is basically allows us to record measurements In this case it's a counter So we'll be increasing or incrementing this counter in our code And then we create a We create a We activate that span in the current context So basically what that means is that context will be implicitly propagated to the other signals and as well to if you had an HTTP client that would be propagating to your upstream as well So we increment that counter by three Just simple instruction with the same attribute And we emit a log record And then we end the span We always need to remember to end the span to stop counting basically So what happens if I run this If I run this script I have not defined where I want my telemetry to be sent Anyone This is a question to you It's a question to you What happens if I run this script Can anyone tell me Will it go to console Commander will be shy Otherwise he'll be talking more Will it go to console Will it fail Will it fail to be like you know I've not defined it So what happens Nah it will do It does nothing And this is one of the magic things of OpenTelemetry is the separation between the API and the You can take that code run it give it to your best friends and go like hey you can run this There is no side effects if you don't configure an SDK Really important if you maintain a library or an application It means that you don't have to decide where the data is sent That can be done by the user when they run the script So I'm going to run this but this time I'm going to use the hotel Java agent which initializes the SDK You can do that in code or you can do that with you know you can use the agent that uses the auto configure API And yeah you can give it a service name We'll give it KCD demo And this time I'll give it an OTP endpoint that we'll point to And that's a local collector that I'm running And then we get correlated signals What you see at the top is that all these signals are coming from the same resource So these three are basically batches of data that the collector is getting right On the left side we've got metrics In the center we've got the trace And on the right hand side we've got logs All of them have the same resource attributes including the process the PID of the process We've got the service name There's a bunch of other attributes And then yeah we've got the counter you know how you increment the value of the actual data point We can see on the left hand side on the bottom you see the trace ID or the exemplar And the trace ID and the span ID that correlates to the trace to the span that you saw there that we created in that context And the log as well will have the same trace and the span ID So all these are now correlated The only thing I had to do was just set an OTP endpoint to my collector and a service name So who defines good telemetry So we talked about all these different signals that you can use but when do you actually use one or the other Who's heard of semantic conventions here Cool right So they are a way to measure and describe common concepts And the result of this is high quality telemetry So it's not just the names and the attributes It doesn't just mean that you define how to name a span or how to name a metric or what attributes to send They also define when to use a signal So if you're thinking about a concept that you want to measure we can say well this should be a metric This should be a span and so on And the result is yeah that sort of stable telemetry that can be used by OTEL and non OTEL libraries Anyone is able to use these semantic conventions In fact we want more people that are not using that are not maintaining open telemetry to start to use these semantic conventions in their applications and their And it's all common language for all platforms as well All vendors can speak the same language All observability platforms can speak the same language and start to provide insights on top of data Who defines the semantic conventions I can tell you it's not this It is not a room where OTEL maintainers go and say okay we're going to name this whatever like you know enduser id We don't come up with this stuff ourselves Wouldn't it be easier It would be a lot easier It would be a lot easier if we just sat in a room and said like we're going to name this this But no it's a collaborative effort right We want to get more maintainers and users and other stakeholders to come and work with us to define these conventions The way that it works is through prototypes So we get some instrumentation packages out there and we say well let's try this out see if it And if it doesn't work well then we'll change it And then everyone will complain because we changed the semantic convention But the idea is that you know it's a collaborative effort and we want more people to be involved in this What about logs though Are there semantic conventions for Yeah of course So as you mentioned there are a lot of areas regarding these attribute registries So we have cross cutting attributes which are basically for each signal metrics traces and logs So for instance if you have log records you can have a code line number attribute which tells you which line of code emitted a You can have an exception message so you know what has crashed And you have also the service name deployment environment so you know what application crashed and where You have also signal specific log attributes So like we're asking for logs So there are also some only related to logs But there are also domain specific attributes which are usually the most important the key which we need also you know your feedback So for instance attributes for HTTP for databases for Gen AI Everyone loves AI And yeah and also there are CICD deployments semantic conventions et cetera Yeah So yeah that's a question for me to you Robert because I think you know logs events what's the difference I think you know we've heard about a lot of discussions about logs versus events So I want to know where it is So I will be talking about open telemetry because there is a lot of confusion what is event and what is log So in open telemetry we define that basically an event is a log record with an event name which defines the structure how the record will look like So if we have an event record we say that it will always have the same set of attributes and it will represent the same thing that happened So basically there's an approximation that a log record says something happened and the event record says that something important has happened that we actually care about so I just prepared a simple example A log record from a logging library can look like this that a user logged into successfully There's some severity for a logging library some additional field And an event record can simply look like this one So we have a semantic convention calling that if the event name is called user login it means that across all other applications and software that it means that a user has logged in And we just need a severity number and attributes so it's more packed and is a common thing across other things Yes so I'll cover this one So basically the important thing so these are purple because these are things that are coming to OpenTelemetry So basically if you remember I was describing this concept of this complex values in attributes and log message body So this type are coming also to traces and metrics and profiles So complex values are coming to all signals because it occurred that people need them as well And now it's up to you Yeah so one of the things that you know when I was talking about semantic conventions you might be thinking okay so that's in the OpenTelemetry site you know common concepts But what do I do if I want to you know maintain my own semantic conventions I would urge everyone to check out Weaver Weaver is a tool that allows you to manage your own semantic convention registry And you can define your own domain specific semantic conventions You can extend semantic conventions from the global registry You can come up with your own ones It allows you to like generate code as well automatically that will basically use your semantic conventions It will allow you to validate registries to integrate it in your CICT The idea here is that observability should be something that you do by design It's not something that comes after you deploy a new feature right It's something that needs to be part of your development workflow to add telemetry to it and to make it And that's what Weaver gives us We have a few a couple of talks as well that will evolve from some of the concepts that we just spoke about today Robert will be talking at KubeCon about logs I would basically if you are at KubeCon Atlanta in a few weeks please go and see Robert's I will also be talking about well the bad side of this Like there's a lot of bad telemetry out there so how do we make it better With Jurassic from another one of my colleagues from the OpenTelemetry Governance Committee And yeah so a couple of key takeaways From my side the main takeaway is there's no single bullet so logs does not work for everything as Dan told And also if you have the semantic conventions make sure that these are recommendations They are common things but you always need to tailor the things to the pieces that you actually need So whenever you're doing anything in software make sure to test everything that you're using Make sure you benchmark your stuff Just make sure that you're not blindly using recommendations Also if something is not working just create an issue and give us feedback And the last one is that you're in charge of the telemetry now Even if you're an application owner or you're a library maintainer the telemetry that you produce is part of the API in a way that you give your users It's part of the data you give them With OpenTelemetry we've seen that you can use the API without having to configure the SDK which means that you can just give people your code and allow them to have agency have ownership of their telemetry Once again I'm asking you to use the OTAIL libraries natively and then give your users the freedom to select where they push their telemetry to That was talking a lot Me as well probably This is the QR code for the slides if you're interested But now it's your time to ask questions It's your time Thank you very Thanks Thank you
